awd_titl_txt: Understanding tree species response to urban heat using high resolution remote sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
Movement of water from the ground up to tree leaf surfaces, where it evaporates, is an important means by which green infrastructure cools cities. This water movement—or transpiration—is also linked to a tree’s ability to store carbon via photosynthesis. However, it is not well understood how different tree species respond to urban heat with respect to maintenance of transpiration at high temperatures or shifts in the dates of leaf development and leaf fall. Thus, cities do not have adequate information to choose the species that are best equipped to thrive under stressful conditions and bolster climate resilience under warming. This project uses drone and satellite imagery analysis to observe these responses in a manner only previously possible under laboratory conditions. This project will increase our understanding of how trees in an urban environment can help to mitigate the warming of cities though the cooling impact of trees.

Information on how species and planting site (e.g., downtown street tree, suburban park tree) influence urban forest transpiration is lacking, in part because it is difficult to account for a city’s high degree of land cover heterogeneity at fine spatial scale. This project accounts for rapid changes in tree response to heat over space and time through use of high-resolution imagery analysis. Drone measurements of leaf temperature and chemistry will be acquired multiple times per day to examine the extent to which photosynthesis and transpiration track one another or diverge. Weekly satellite imagery capable of measuring leaf abundance at the individual tree scale across a large city will be used to assess changes in urban forest start and end of season, a fundamental control on seasonal transpiration. These analyses are among the first to provide observational evidence of how urban tree function may be altered by increased heat at daily and seasonal increments.

por.por_cntn:
Cities are more than just buildings and roads—trees can also be considered a critical urban infrastructure in that they moderate temperature, clean the air, and support biodiversity. This project investigated how urban trees influence local climate conditions and how different species respond to environmental stressors. By integrating high-resolution satellite imagery, drone-mounted thermal and spectral sensors, and ground-based monitoring, we explored how trees mitigate urban heat and how their physiological responses shape their role in urban ecosystems.

A primary goal of the project was to understand the phenological cycles of urban trees—when they start and end their growing seasons—and how these cycles are influenced by species traits and planting site conditions. Using high-resolution satellite imagery, we tracked leaf-out and leaf senescence across different urban settings. We show that urban heat is indeed an important driver of phenological shifts but that species  and planting site selection (and how those vary by density and other neighborhood characteristics) can matter even more. This idea becomes more apparent when considering the co-occurrence of turf grass and trees in highly managed zones. Moderate resolution satellite images mix these two plant types in amounts that vary by management strategy, reducing the reliability of estimates of tree canopy phenological sensitivity.

We also examined how urban tree canopy affects air temperature at different times of day. In our multiple publications on this topic, we used bike- and car-mounted temperature sensors in twelve Northeastern USA cities. Previous research has either relied on land surface temperature or has been limited in geographic extent. We found that each additional tree has the greatest air cooling effect in areas that already have >25% canopy, corroborating earlier reports that forest patches are important for urban heat mitigation. We further showed that canopy-cooling magnitudes reported from studies using satellite-based land surface temperature were 4-11x greater than air temperature. However, it is air temperature that is more closely linked to human health and comfort. Canopy-cooling may additionally be overstated in studies that do not account for other determinants of urban temperature (e.g., impervious surface cover, water bodies) or by a sampling bias towards hot, clear days. While our results confirmed that extensive canopy patches provide midday cooling, we also found that scattered trees can provide significant cooling benefits in the late afternoon and evening. This is especially important in cities, where space constraints often limit the development of large green spaces. Our findings suggest that strategic, distributed tree planting can be an effective tool for mitigating urban heat, particularly in areas where extensive canopy cover is not feasible.

A key component of this project involved monitoring tree canopy temperature using drone-mounted thermal cameras, which is an important step towards monitoring transpiration remotely. Trees regulate their temperature through transpiration, a process that varies across species and environmental conditions. This variability is difficult to monitor using common, invasive measurements of tree water use. However, it is also challenging to work with thermal imagery from a drone-mounted camera, especially when the camera is not cooled. Therefore, we developed methods to correct hourly drone data using reference panels or nearby non-transpiring surfaces such that we could examine daily trends in canopy temperature for a large set of individual trees. We found that canopy temperature (and likely transpiration) was controlled by a combination of species attributes (e.g., leaf area), atmospheric conditions (e.g., air temperature and humidity), and soil moisture. We concluded that drone thermal data has potential for determining species sensitivity to atmospheric conditions. These methods open the door for studying tree water relations for larger numbers of trees and across more diverse environments.

Finally, we explored how tree physiological traits, such as photosynthetic activity and water stress, can be estimated using remote sensing techniques. A major challenge in urban ecology is scaling up physiological measurements from individual leaves to entire tree crowns and beyond. To facilitate this scaling, we measured hundreds of leaves with both a portable photosynthesis system, to measure traits directly, and a field spectrometer, which measures how the full range of wavelengths in sunlight reflect off of a leaf. If, for example, red light is mostly absorbed by leaf chlorophyll, it would indicate strong photosynthetic function. Our findings indicate that photosynthetic parameters, such as electron transport rate, can be effectively modeled using visible and near-infrared wavelengths, but leaf water potential remains difficult to estimate from this data. These results pave the way for future studies to use airborne and satellite-based spectroscopy to assess urban tree functions at broader scales.
